awd_titl_txt: Methane isotopologue fractionation during microbial methanogenesis and methonotrophy by pure and mixed laboratory cultures
awd_abstract_narration:
Methane is both an alternative energy source and a strong greenhouse gas. It is important to understand its sources and sinks for the future of our energy and environment. A group of microbes, called methanogens, is the major source of methane to the atmosphere as well as to methane hydrates in deep sediments. Methane is composed of one C and four H atoms. Each has two isotopes, 13C/12C and D/H, respectively. Microbial methane is often depleted in heavy isotopes of carbon and hydrogen as well as a doubly substituted isotopologue (13CH3D) because of the different reactivity of isotopologues (isotope substituted molecules). In this project, investigators will carry out a series of laboratory experiments, including bioelectrochemical systems and co-cultures, to examine the major control of methane isotopologue fractionations by methanogenic microbes. The goal is to construct a unified model that links isotopologue ratios of microbial methane to environmental and physiological parameters, in order to develop methane isotopologue ratios as a diagnostic tool for its source. The project will support a graduate student, and promotes partnership between the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and Aerodyne Research Inc. The laboratory of the investigator will participate in K-12 outreach programs to demonstrate microbial fuel cells and the use of isotopes in biogeochemistry. 

Carbon and hydrogen isotope ratios have been widely used to trace the origin of methane in the environment. In addition to bulk isotope ratios, the abundance of doubly substituted methane isotopologues (13CH3D) has been proposed as a gauge of methane formation temperature. While these proxies are used as a tool to fingerprint the source(s) of methane, they often yield data that are inconsistent with other geochemical parameters. This proposed research aims to identify the major control(s) of methane isotopologue fractionation during microbial methanogenesis and methanotrophy from a series of controlled laboratory culture experiments using 1) bioelectrochemical systems under well-defined redox potentials, 2) co-cultures of sulfate reducing bacteria and methanogens, and 3) cultures of aerobic and anaerobic methanotrophs. Four isotopologue compositions of methane (12CH4, 13CH4, 12CH3D, & 13CH3D) will be measured by a novel tunable infrared laser direct absorption spectroscopy (TILDAS) instrument. Investigators will test the hypotheses that the rate of methanogenesis or methanotrophy and the redox potential of the environment, rather than the pathway, impart the major control on isotopologue fractionation, and whether isotopologue equilibrium requires anaerobic oxidation of methane or other specific microbial community structures.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Methane is a significant greenhouse gas and an important energy source, making it essential to understand its origins in the environment to develop effective strategies for mitigating its impact on climate change. A group of microbes known as methanogens is a major source of methane, producing emissions into the atmosphere and methane hydrates trapped in deep sediments.

To trace the origins of methane, scientists study isotopologues, molecules of methane with slight isotopic differences. These isotopologues serve as chemical fingerprints, helping us identify methane sources. Traditionally, it was thought that isotopologue signals were primarily determined by specific microbial pathways, such as hydrogenotrophic or acetoclastic methanogenesis, or by anaerobic oxidation of methane. However, our research demonstrates that the driving factors are thermodynamic conditions and the reversibility of methanogenesis rather than the specific metabolic pathway.

Our studies, as described in Mayumi et al. (2024), identified total pressure and thermodynamic drive as critical factors influencing isotopologue fractionation. Laboratory experiments revealed that cultures producing near-equilibrium isotopologue fractionations operate at a free energy yield of 15 kJ/mol CH4, close to the theoretical minimum required for microbial metabolism. Furthermore, Ono et al. (2021) showed that anaerobic oxidation of methane under controlled conditions produces kinetic isotopologue signals, not near-equilibrium signals. These findings emphasize the role of thermodynamic constraints in shaping isotopologue patterns, particularly under high-pressure and low-energy conditions.

To better interpret isotopologue data, Ono et al. (2022) developed a model that integrates pathway thermodynamics with an isotopologue flow network. This approach allows researchers to predict variables, such as metabolite concentrations, that are otherwise difficult to measure and estimate the reversibility of metabolic processes. This model provides a valuable framework for analyzing isotopologue signals across diverse environmental settings.

Our research explains why isotopologue patterns differ between environments. In high-pressure, low-energy marine sediments, methane isotopologues often approach equilibrium patterns. In contrast, methane produced in near-surface environments such as wetlands and ruminant systems exhibits kinetic isotopologue signals due to less stringent energy constraints. These findings provide a more comprehensive understanding of methane isotopologue systematics and improve the ability to trace methane’s origins. Focusing on thermodynamic and kinetic controls, our results present a unified model for methane isotopologue fractionations and contribute to a deeper understanding of methane’s role in global biogeochemical cycles.

The project partially supported three graduate students and one postdoctoral associate, trained for culturing microbes and methane isotopologue analysis using a tunable laser spectroscopy instrument.
